title: Long-standing Severe to Profound Sensorineural Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: My hearing has continued to decline, and I am struggling to hear in most situations. I can't use the phone anymore because I can hear the voice but can't understand the words.

problem_summary.onset: Began decreasing bilaterally over 20 years ago.
problem_summary.course: Progressive decline; currently on second pair of hearing aids (started amplification 12 years ago).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Inability to understand speech without visual cues (lip reading).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Cannot use telephone for understanding; struggles in most daily situations despite amplification.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking help due to continued decline and lack of benefit from current hearing aids.

history.present_illness: Patient reports bilateral hearing decrease starting >20 years ago. He has used amplification for 12 years and is on his second pair of aids. He reports continued decline and significant struggle in most environments.
history.prior_management: Has used hearing aids for 12 years (currently on 2nd pair).
history.patient_goals: To improve speech understanding, particularly on the phone and in conversation.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Severe sensorineural hearing loss at 250-2000 Hz, sloping to profound at 3000-8000 Hz bilaterally. Symmetrical configuration.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs are in agreement with PTAs. Word recognition scores are poor to very poor bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent acoustic reflexes with ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation from 500 to 4,000 Hz. Reflex decay not measured due to absent thresholds.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a symmetrical, severe sensorineural hearing loss from 250-2000 Hz, sloping to profound hearing loss in the high frequencies (3000-8000 Hz). Word recognition is poor (54% AD, 48% AS), indicating significant distortion and loss of clarity that volume alone cannot correct. Middle ear function is normal.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss has progressed to a severe-to-profound level, which explains why you are struggling even with hearing aids.
Your ability to understand words (clarity) is quite low (around 50%), meaning even when speech is loud enough, it may not be clear.
Because of your poor speech understanding scores, traditional hearing aids may no longer provide enough benefit.
We are referring you to an ENT specialist to evaluate you for a Cochlear Implant, which may provide better access to speech than hearing aids.
notes_for_actor: You rely heavily on lip-reading. If the audiologist looks down or covers their mouth, you should indicate you cannot understand them.
You are frustrated. You have tried hearing aids for 12 years, but they just aren't working well anymore.
Emphasize the isolation of not being able to use the phone.
